repnme.cdata!:
Land policy : securing rights to reduce
            poverty and promote rural growth

abstracts.cdata!:
Modern, efficient, and transparent land
            administration systems are important in reducing poverty,
            and promoting growth and sustainable development. Security
            of property rights is central to preserving livelihoods,
            maintaining social stability, and increasing incentives for
            investment and for sustainable, productive land use. Making
            land rights transferable allows the landless to access land
            through sales and rental markets or through public
            transfers, and further increases investment incentives.
            Since the late 1960s, the World Bank has provided financing,
            technical help, and training to strengthen national land
            administration laws, policies, and investment programs.

docna.cdata!:
Land policy : securing rights to reduce
            poverty and promote rural growth

display_title.display_title:
Land policy : securing rights to
            reduce poverty and promote rural growth

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Land administration policy - To
            promote rural growth and reduce poverty

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on Land Policy, Securing the
            rights to reduce poverty and promote rural growth points out
            that modern systems of efficient and transparent land
            administration are important to reduce poverty and promote
            growth and sustainable development. It is essential to
            ensure the property rights to protect livelihoods, maintain
            social stability and increasing incentives for investment
            and for sustainable use and productive land. The report adds
            that since the late 60's, the World Bank provides
            financing, technical assistance and training to strengthen
            legislation, investment policies and programs on national
            land administration.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Urban development - Poverty
            reduction and promoting growth for urbanization

abstracts.cdata!:
This report on poverty reduction and
            promoting growth for urbanization as an aspect of urban
            development in Tunisia claims the World Bank aims to respond
            to both aspects of the challenge posed by urbanization by
            firstly, helping governments prepare proactively for new
            urban growth and, secondly, supporting improved service
            delivery for urban poor. In view of these goals, the
            institution will provide support for urban development
            through five types of activities, namely, 1) management,
            financing and management of cities; 2) improving urban
            poverty and poor housing; 3) cities and economic growth; 4)
            planning, housing and urban land; and 5) urban and disaster
            management and climate change.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Land Titling
            Project (LTP II) for Laos were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            reform of land administration is a long-term endeavor that
            requires decades of investment of capital and human
            resources and sustained commitment. However, the path
            towards reform of land reform is rarely straight-forward,
            and commitment on the part of authorities is often neither
            sustained nor consistent. Thus, a support strategy should
            balance a clear sense of direction and priorities with a
            significant dose of pragmatism. This project could have
            benefited from a more stable policy framework and closer
            engagement between the donors and the government. It is
            important that reform is demand driven, i.e. by the
            government, rather than supply driven, i.e. by the donors.
            There is a risk when measurement of project impact depends
            on a self-standing study to be completed toward the end of
            the life of the project. In the case of LTP II, relying too
            heavily on a self-standing impact assessment unrelated to
            the ongoing monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system
            resulted in the inability to fully measure the
            project's impact.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Land Titling Project for Laos
            will be the second phase o f the long term land titling
            program aiming at the development o f the land
            administration capacity to support the country's
            economic  development and poverty reduction goals. The
            project would contribute to the government's National
            Poverty Eradication Program (NPEP) under preparation. The
            objectives o f the project are to (i) improve  the security
            o f land tenure; (ii) develop transparent and efficient land
            administration institutions at the  national and provincial
            levels; and (iii) improve the government's capacity to
            provide social and  economic services through broader
            revenue base from property related fees and taxes. These
            objectives  would be achieved through formulating and
            approving land policy and regulatory changes, strengthening
            institutional capacity and project management, accelerating
            land titling activities in areas o f high  demand,
            developing and implementing an efficient and transparent
            land registration system, and  strengthening land valuation
            systems. There are 5 project components. Component 1
            provides support to develop the land policy and regulatory
            framework, and specifically helps to develop the
            government's capacity to formulate land policies and
            establishes a coordination mechanism for land information.
            Component 2 supports long-term development of the Department
            of Lands and the Provincial Land Office; provides training
            and human resources development; and supports education in
            the areas of land administration, land management, and
            property valuation. Component 3 develops a modern land
            registration system by helping land offices operate
            according to agreed standards, providing community education
            and services, strengthening land valuation to support land
            registration, and supporting the Department of State Assets
            Management. Component 4 accelerates land registration
            through systematic registration. Component 5 supports
            project management and implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Laos, Peoples Democratic Republic of -
            Second Land Titling Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Land Titling Project, as a
            contributory factor to urban management, will facilitate
            future road plans, associated runoff drainage, and footpath
            plans, within the legal and regulatory frameworks, supported
            by the necessary technical capability. Nonetheless, setting
            land titling (LT) boundaries may potentially come in
            conflict with road widening, or construction lines, where a
            variety of public services could be held up, made more
            expensive, or abandoned altogether, causing serious public
            health consequences. Similarly, illegal landfills, and/or
            when at illegal distances from water courses (thus
            encouraging natural drainage uses), may compromise
            acceptance of LT boundaries, since this issue could have
            serious flooding, and public health consequences. To this
            end, this environmental assessment looks at mitigation
            measures, by ensuring the availability of town plans that
            include land titling maps, revised and approved by the Town
            Planning Office. In addition, mediation at the District
            Governor's level will be available as necessary,
            including administrative support should grievances occur.
            The report further includes an annex regarding social
            impacts, and ethnic peoples assessment, to better understand
            the nature, and behavior of customary land rights among
            various ethnic groups in urban, and peri-urban settings,
            and, how - if at all - could the project affect customary
            land laws.
